title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates that unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code. This includes any applicable child support payments required to be paid for the support of a child. The term 'taxable unpaid child support payments' refers to payments that the taxpayer was required to pay under a support instrument for the support of their child, and for which notice requirements must be met. The eligible taxpayer must send a notice to the individual who failed to make payments in the second calendar year following a year in which a deduction was claimed under section 166(f). The eligible taxpayer must send a notice to the individual who failed to make payments in the calendar year following a year in which a deduction was claimed under section 166(f), containing the amount of applicable child support payments and a requirement to include this amount in gross income for the preceding taxable year. If the taxpayer does not have the individual's address, the Secretary will provide the notice. The eligible taxpayer must send a notice to the individual regarding the amount of child support payments to be included in gross income for the preceding taxable year. If the taxpayer does not have the individual's address, the Secretary will provide the notice. If no address is known, no income shall be included for any taxable year before the year in which the notice may be sent. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Subsequent child support payments included in gross income can be deducted in the year of payment. Definitions for 'applicable child support payments' and 'eligible taxpayer' are provided in section 166(f). SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments remaining at the end of the taxable year for eligible taxpayers. This deduction is limited per child. The amendment to Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments at the end of the taxable year, with a limit of $10,000 per child. Eligible taxpayers must have an adjusted gross income below $50,000, unpaid child support payments of at least $500, and meet identification requirements. The amendment allows eligible taxpayers with an adjusted gross income under $50,000 and unpaid child support of $500 or more to deduct applicable child support payments at the end of the taxable year. The term 'support payment' refers to periodic fixed payments or payments for medical, educational, or insurance expenses required to be paid by an individual under a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. A qualifying child is defined as a child for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151 for the taxable year. The term 'support payment' refers to periodic fixed payments or payments for medical, educational, or insurance expenses required to be paid by an individual under a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. A qualifying child is defined as a child of an eligible individual for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151 for the taxable year. Any payment required to be made by an individual to an eligible taxpayer shall not be treated as an applicable unpaid child support payment if at least half of the payments required to be paid to the eligible taxpayer during the 12-month period ending on the last. In the case of child support payments, if at least half of the required payments to the eligible taxpayer are made during the 12-month period, it will not be considered as unpaid child support. Additionally, payments assigned to a State under the Social Security Act are not included as applicable child support payments. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under the Social Security Act. Identification requirements for claiming the deduction include providing the child's information and the individual responsible for making the payments. In order to claim the deduction for child support payments, the taxpayer must provide information about the child and the individual responsible for the payments. Cost-of-living adjustments are made to the specified dollar amounts for taxable years after 2000. For taxable years after 2000, specified dollar amounts for deductions related to child support payments are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Subsequent payments that were previously deducted must be included in the taxpayer's gross income for the year in which they are made. For taxable years after 2000, specified dollar amounts for deductions related to child support payments are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Subsequent payments previously deducted must be included in the taxpayer's gross income for the year in which they are made, unless the right to receive such payments has been assigned to a State. A support instrument includes decrees of divorce or separate maintenance, written separation agreements, or other legal documents. A support instrument for child support includes decrees of divorce or separate maintenance, written separation agreements, or court orders requiring parental payments. The deduction for unpaid child support payments is allowed under section 166(f) of the tax code. A conforming amendment is made to section 166(d)(2) of the tax code. The tax code allows a deduction for unpaid child support payments under section 166(f). Amendments to sections 62(a) and 166(d)(2) are made to accommodate this change, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will solely retire US public debt, not for other purposes, regardless of other laws.
